node.title: What do historians say about Craig Kelly's claim about 'possibly the largest ever political rally'?
node.alt: Graphic of coronavirus blob with spikes with the header CoronaCheck
node.description: United Australia Party MP Craig Kelly says recent COVID protests in Melbourne were 'possibly the largest ever political rally' in Australia. Here's what the experts have to say
node.content:
["CoronaCheck is RMIT ABC Fact Check's weekly email newsletter dedicated to fighting the misinformation infodemic surrounding the coronavirus outbreak.", "You can read the latest edition below, and\u00a0subscribe\u00a0to have the next newsletter delivered straight to your inbox.", "
CoronaCheck #93
", "This week's edition of CoronaCheck looks into United Australia Party leader Craig Kelly's claim that a recent protest against Victoria's proposed pandemic legislation was \"possibly the largest ever political rally in Australia\".", "We also debunk claims that COVID-19 vaccines have led to a surge in the number of soccer players collapsing on field, and bring you the latest academic research into climate misinformation.", "
Was a recent protest rally in Melbourne 'possibly the largest ever' in Australia?
", "United Australia Party leader and federal MP Craig Kelly has used social media to document his attendance at various \"freedom\" rallies taking place across the nation.", "On November 17, the MP\u00a0tweeted\u00a0that a rally held the previous Saturday in Melbourne's CBD, in which protesters campaigned against Victoria's proposed pandemic legislation, was \"possibly the largest ever political rally in Australia\".", "\"To see 10s of thousands people as far as the eye could see is an experience I'll never forget,\" he said.", "But could that be right?", "Not according to Frank Bongiorno, a political historian at the Australian National University, who suggested Mr Kelly's statement \"isn't accurate\".", "\"So far as I know, the largest [protests] were very likely 8 May 1970 (First Anti-Vietnam War Moratorium March in Melbourne) and 10 November 1992 (Anti-Kennett in Melbourne over industrial relations),\" he said via an email.", "Those demonstrations each\u00a0reportedly\u00a0attracted\u00a0an estimated 100,000 protesters.", "", "
Archival footage from the 1970 demonstrations in Melbourne against the Vietnam War.
", "\"Unless there were also 100,000 marching in Melbourne last week, the claim isn't accurate,\" Professor Bongiorno, who is head of the School of History at ANU, said of Mr Kelly's tweet.", "He added the Invasion Day rally held in Melbourne in January 2019 was one of the biggest of recent times, attracting 40,000 people.", "According to various media outlets (including the\u00a0ABC, the\u00a0Guardian, the\u00a0Age,\u00a0Channel 7,\u00a0Channel 9,\u00a0Sky News,\u00a0and\u00a0SBS) \"thousands\" of people attended the rally in Melbourne on November 13.", "Another rally held a week later reportedly attracted \"tens of thousands\" of protesters,\u00a0according to\u00a0Sky News\u00a0and\u00a0the Australian.", "No media reports suggested crowds reached 100,000 at either rally, despite the claims of protest organisers.", "A Victoria Police spokesperson declined to provide Fact Check with any official estimates.", "It's worth noting, however, that estimating protest attendance figures is fraught.", "In an\u00a0article\u00a0published by The Conversation, Stephen Doig, a data journalist and journalism professor at Arizona State University, explained why it is difficult to determine an accurate number for crowds.", "\"It's actually a difficult thing to do,\" he wrote.", "\"Then there are all sorts of political reasons the sizes of crowds get either inflated or deflated. The size of a crowd has become a token of popularity of whatever the cause that gathered the crowd is, whether it's a political event like this, or sports or a celebration. Inevitably, the estimate of the size of the crowd is sort of vastly larger than reality.\"", "Professor Bongiorno echoed these sentiments.", "\"Historians have had to deal with sources for decades that clash with one another about crowd size estimates, even when dealing with protests in the 1800s,\" he noted.", "
No, vaccines are not killing all the footballers
", "", "
Danish soccer player Christian Eriksen collapsed on field in June.(AP: Wolfgang Rattay)
", "While social media users may be shocked to see posts listing many athletes and footballers who have collapsed or died in the last year, there is no mysterious new epidemic of heart problems linked to COVID-19 jabs.", "\"We have to stop the psychos vaxxing our young people,\" reads a Facebook post from New Zealand's Outdoors Party, which catalogued around 90 apparent medical emergencies among athletes in at least 20 countries.", "Many of the same names have been shared by Australian users of Facebook and Telegram, in lists featuring European footballers and teenage athletes in the US, among others.", "Fact Check has analysed a sample of these lists, finding they include deaths from heatstroke, on-field collision and apparent suicide, along with retired players, a golf caddie and other cases lacking any verifiable details.", "For numerous cases, it was not possible to draw conclusions about an athlete's medical condition from the publicly available information.", "Although news reports suggest multiple athletes have indeed suffered from heart problems, experts told Fact Check that such cases were not uncommon among athletes, and were not on the rise.", "Andre La Gerche, the Baker Institute's head of sports cardiology, explained that sudden cardiac arrest, or SCA, often hits people without any history of heart problems.", "\"Nearly half the time, we have no idea why, even after an autopsy,\" he said, noting that this would usually reveal whether myocarditis was a factor.", "(Myocarditis is a relatively rare and typically mild side-effect of mRNA vaccines, which causes inflammation of the heart muscle).", "Rates vary depending on age, but Dr La Gerche said SCA affects about 1 in 50,000 athletes aged 30 and under, and that, for any age group, it causes three to five times more deaths than car accidents.", "\"So the inference that those cases are somehow due to the vaccine is wrong, because that has been happening well before [the pandemic],\" he said, adding that in Victoria, data from paramedics showed no increase in these incidents.", "Still, Dr La Gerche said he expected to see more cases of vaccine-related myocarditis in athletes, simply because young men, who are more likely to experience this side-effect, are also statistically more likely to be athletes.", "In the US, the Outcomes Registry for Cardiac Conditions in Athletes is tracking heart conditions among college athletes during the pandemic.", "Dr Jonathan Drezner, one of the register's principal investigators, told Fact Check there \"has not been an increase in sudden cardiac arrest or death in young athletes\".", "He labelled the lists as \"misinformation and wrong\", adding that the risk of heart problems from COVID-19 (1:200) was 100 times greater than that of vaccine-related myocarditis (1:20,000), and that he knew of just two cases of SCA linked to the disease.", "Meanwhile, AFP Fact Check has\u00a0debunked posts on German social media\u00a0claiming to show a steep rise in sudden cardiac deaths among footballers in Europe.", "AFP's analysis of data from the international football federation's (FIFA) Sudden Death Registry showed that, for the year to date, there had been proportionally fewer deaths from heart attack than in 2018, while experts said using social media lists to make comparisons with previous years was meaningless without standardised methodology.", "
In other news: Debunking past messaging may allow us to predict future climate change denialism
", "", "
Can artificial intelligence predict climate change misinformation?(UN Photo: Mark Garten)
", "A\u00a0new report\u00a0has found that climate change misinformation largely falls into five categories, allowing researchers to train a machine-learning model to automatically detect bad information.", "The report, published in Nature, examined climate messaging and constructed a detailed history of climate change contrarianism between 1998 and 2020, based on 255,449 documents from 20 prominent conservative think tanks and 33 central contrarian blogs.", "According to the report, climate myths followed five identifiable themes: it's not real, it's not us, it's not bad, solutions won't work, and climate science is unreliable.", "The researchers found that climate contrarianism messaging had shifted over time, with \"it's not bad\" being the dominant message in 2000. As climate change science became more prominent and undeniable, \"solutions won't work\" messaging took hold, giving way by 2020 to claims that the \"climate science is unreliable\".", "The study also found that climate misinformation narratives repeated themselves over time.", "In an email,\u00a0John Cook, a postdoctoral research fellow with the Monash Climate Change Communication Research Hub and one of the study's authors, explained: \"The argument goes that global warming stopped in 2016, by plotting temperature trends from the record hot year in 2016. It's exactly the same misleading technique as 'global warming stopped in 1998' that was used prior to 2016.\"", "He added that the past helped to predict future messaging.", "\"Our data shows that when you apply a certain stimuli (for example, introduction of climate legislation), you see spikes in certain types of misinformation (eg, arguing climate policy is harmful),\" Dr Cook said.", "\"This predictability makes it possible to anticipate future surges in climate misinformation such as in the lead up to a COP event.\"", "Dr Cook also revealed that he had been working with Facebook on addressing climate misinformation for the last year and had been talking to the social media behemoth about this machine-learning research.\"Facebook has been using the taxonomy we developed in this study with it's five main categories to inform how they choose myths to fact-check (to make sure they get myths across the different categories).", "\"We have also collaborated with them on detecting specific climate misinformation claims using their own methods.\"", "Edited by Ellen McCutchan\u00a0with thanks to David Campbell, Matt Harvey and Olivia Thomson", "Got a fact that needs checking? Tweet us\u00a0@ABCFactCheck\u00a0or send us an email at\u00a0factcheck@rmit.edu.au", "", "
This newsletter is supported by funding from the Judith Nielson Institute for Journalism and Ideas(Judith Nielson Institute)
"]
